Growing up one thing I always loved to do was unclog the shower, or clean roof gutters, a visceral reward from clearing a path to let things flow – working with data / computers gives me that feeling sometimes (which I think is why I still do it)

was having a conversation lately with @enjalot – he was talking about how there is an innately rewarding feeling that comes with sorting through a large amount of things for a small thing that is good, and finding it. That's an experience you can find a lot of ways, data is one.
10 years of processing data and it still feels like magic

In conclusion- I can design any three dimensional object, send the design to a warehouse in Greenpoint, and basically make any object exist in 48 hours, but god forbid I tell my representatives how they should vote in an accountable way that gives me feedback and autonomy

What was so pernicious to me about 2016 election meddling was that we were all so starry-eyed about the potential for Twitter to properly convey underrepresented views from the electorate we didn't think of the myriad ways that the system could be gamed
We take polls (privately-funded, usually lacking in rigor or sample size) and then our representatives choose (or don't!) to follow the will of their constituents by referencing said polls.

America; we have the technology to ask everyone in any place what they think about everything in real-time, but lack the technology for properly incorporate those views into our representative democracy.

posts.title: Lack Of Data
posts.dek: An exploration of what we choose to track, and what we don't – and what that means if we want to make the world a better place
